item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Plants don’t use much of the UV spectrum, if at all any.

They rely on two major areas: red and blue, red being more important (at certain times).

Blue is important early in their life, and red is almost primarily used for flowering, but it still needs some blue.

The only lamps that he would use that would get hot would be incandescent (worst kind) and a HPS or MH. But then again, HPS or MH is NOT the way to not get caught. They come in higher wattages, are a shit ton brighter, need to put a few feet from the plants, and get really really hot. Neither of those ideas are good because you have such a small amount growing.

Fluorescent lights would be his best bet for indoors, because you don’t have to “insulate” them from any excess heat. And you can place them just inches from your plants.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @Creme_de_la_Creme Creme de la Creme
item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

zammyking111:

whats the most cost effective way of growing them inside? and whats the best way of not getting caught for growing them inside Because there was a big ass storm where i live, even though it didn’t hurt them, it made them lay down fully cause the rain was owning them hard… But i put a splint in there and laid them on it and they are growing back upwards again. But ill update pics so u guys will basically see them from start till finish. I’ll even get ya’ll pics of it in a blunt and smoking it!

As I read that I heard a massive rumble in the background and within 10 seconds started belting it down with rain.

That’s what I was wondering with the lighting. If plants can actually use UV light you can essentially grow your plants in ‘darkness’. If the lamps (whatever type you use) get hot then you’ll need to insulate them, then insulate them again, then insulate the room and your roof if possible for best security.

If you’re going to use heating (which you’re probably not) then you definitely need insulation everywhere - tinfoil, heat absorbers, loft insulation etc. It would also be best to grow them downstairs so when the heat escapes from your house it’s negligible. If you don’t they will eventually catch you with regular heli scans.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Creme de la Creme:

Out of interest, what wavelength of light do plants actually need? Is it just normal visible light or do they need small amounts of UV? What intensity is recommended for normal growth (as in under direct sunlight)

You can grow them with all sorts of lights.

Fluorescent lights, metal halide, and sodium pressure are the most common.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @Creme_de_la_Creme Creme de la Creme
item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:48, topic:271494”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=358252.msg2747460#msg2747460 date=1239718112]
I can’t remember, might not have anything to do with UV, and it might just be red.

For some reason I just remember blue.
[/quote]

Actualy Violet Light has a wavelength of 400 nm while blue light is 475 nm.
Blu-ray uses blue lightwaves while CDs use red light.(That explains why blue > red) If someone makes disc media read with Violet light it should hold even more data than Blu-ray

http://eosweb.larc.nasa.gov/EDDOCS/images/Erb/wavelength_figure.jpg[/quote]

That doesn’t explain anything…

Read full topic

item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:45, topic:271494”]It’s particular colours (wavelengths) found in UV light afaik.

They use a very narrow part of the spectrum, off the top of my head it’s blue and red, but you’ll have to lookup the wavelengths because I don’t remember them.[/quote]

Blue and red are at almost opposite ends of the visible spectrum, are you sure? I’d also swear UV was invisible unless it’s the lower energy (violet) wavelength.

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Didn’t notice he uploaded new pictures. I can see it is weed now.

About them flopping over, keep a fan on them. Or some sort of wind, and they will grow a harder thicker stem. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: April 12, 2009, 11:07:39 am[/size][hr][quote=“zammyking111, post:39, topic:271494”]well they’re getting sunlight from like 11:00 AM till 7:00 PM… So it should be cutting it ;)[/quote]

That’s definitely not enough. Even at the end of the flowering stage, still not enough. You need like 16 hours of light a day, 24 hours a day would be great but I guess not an option.
Like STH said don’t move them inside and outside often.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Direct sunlight or what?
And how are they getting it?

It certainly doesn’t look like it’s cutting it.

This is healthy growth for weed.

What’s going to happen with yours is when it gets it’s second and third set of leaves and they get bigger, it’ll tip over.

In this case, the cold might actually be good. The cold will stunt it’s growth and make it grow thicker rather than taller.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Jme the stems are too long because they’re growing “leggy” because of a lack of light.

As far as what plant, I don’t really care.

But I don’t think they’re going to last. You can’t keep drastically changing their conditions, that puts them into shock. They don’t look very strong. A small gust of wind could knock one over and it’s gone. You need some SRS light for indoor growth, and I don’t think what you have going on is cutting it, because they are leggy.

Read full topic

item.title: You like? [Updated] [Comment] 4/11/09
item.dc:creator: @evilkingofpersia evilkingofpersia
item.description:
@evilkingofpersia wrote:

You cant keep them in a fucking closed drawer...

Yeah you could just make sure it’s open for some time each day, make some holes for air, and use a tube with a fan to keep it circulating. Of course you would need a lamp in the desk drawer too. Weed is a mighty plant though it can grow hardily most places.

Read full topic
